element_texts.text: Third Anniversary Sermon.  Oct. 10th 1880.  The Cloud of Glory in the The House of the Lord.  Then the house was filled with a cloud even the house of the Lord; -- for the Glory of the Lord had filled the house of God. 2. Chron. 5: 13, 14.  Introduction.  History of the Glory Cloud.  What it was to the Jews.  Protection - Guidance - Beauty.  Its Symbolism.  What the Cloud was to the Jews.  X is to us = God manifested.  Its abode in the Temple - X in His Church.  It filled the house - Fullness in X. Its abode there denoted God's approval.  It betokened that from thence Salvation was to go forth.

= Power - judgment and Mercy were manifested there.  The Great Occasion.  When these manifestations of Glory occurred.  1. When they were ready to give up the house entirely to the Service of the Lord.  2. When the Holy Place was cleared of every thing Else.  3. When they offered praise - not Sacrifice.  Especially when they magnified the mercy and goodness of God.  4. When they were one. Cymbals. Psalteries. Harps. Trumpets. = All distinctions pass away in the presence of X.

Review of the Years Work.  
Glory Cloud has been over us - Reasons for Gratitude.  
1. We entered upon the Year experimentally = Financial Strength was to be ascertained = All bills are paid.  Cash on hand about $14.00.  Good unpaid Subscriptions - $70.  Subscription list for next year - 
Hindrances - Unfavorable place of meeting- only 70 resident members.  Four of best men travelling.  
2. The work in general has been pleasant.  No great upheaval - but during all the first part of the year a continuous blessing

= Peace - and Harmony.  
3. Changes in Membership - At beginning of the year - 115 Members.  Dismissed 8 Excluded 1 = 9.  Received by Bap. 5  by letter 10 = 15.  Net gain of 6 - Present No. 121.  
We have an admirable System of Church Work - Explain.

Trial of Abraham's Faith
For now I know that thou fearest God.
Gen. 22:12.
Introduction
Notice encouragements God gives to faith.
The great work of life is to believe.  "This is the work of God that ye believe on Him whom He hath sent." 
= Helps to faith abundant.  John's Gospel.  These were written that ye might believe + so the miracles  - Promises-
= Special Illustration in case of Abraham.  God designed to make him the father of many nations   But this was too much for A. to take in at first trace___1. His call to go unto a land yet to be made known 12:1; 2. Jehovah's appearance at Shechem. 12:7x;    3;   When he came back from Egypt. "Seed as the dust" 13:16x    4. When he made a Cov. with A. Growing old. no heir. "Fear not A." "Look now toward heaven". "Whereby shall I know this?" Then the Cov. 15:1+ x     5. Cov ratified change of namex 17:5x. Then Isaac was born.

I  The Trial of Abraham's Faith x 
After increasing it. growing it to the extent required God tries it x 
Ills. The founder of a bell.  Tried it with a hammer x
Ills. Napoleon's Artisan and coat of mail x
=The trial not for God but to make faith real to A-
Ills The Soldier needs battle in order to make soldiers life real.
= Faith's idea involved the heroic element
= We may be self-deceived in two ways -
1. We may think we have faith when we have it not.  or
2. We may think we do not have it when we do have it x
Ills Affliction often tests Char. in this way

II. How God tried Abraham's faith.
= It was in a way to put it to the severest test x 
So He tries us.  One in one way another in an-
Sickness__Trouble__Loss of property. Affliction.
= How it was with Abraham.
1. Severe because of its connection with past trials x 
Called to leave his home.  Childless old age.
Driving out of Hagar.  now Isaac x 
2. Severe because it was to break a natural tie x
Son. only son. whom thou lovest.
3. Severe because it stood against all human probabilities x
Isaac. son of promise. In case of Hagar a reason was given. but here none x

III. Victory of Abraham's faith .
1. He had faith to retain the blessing as well as to receive it .
2. Prompt obedience.  trace it .
IV. Reward of Abraham's faith .
1. Gods recognition of that faith _ "Now I know &c"
2. Gods oath _ " that in blessing" &c
Conclusion
1. Murmur not at trials
2. Jehovah Jireh lies in the path of him who walks by faith.
3. The value of Jesus as a Substitute for us depends upon our willingness to part with the dearest object of our affs.
"If any man come to me and hate not &c" He that seeks to save his life shall lose it etc
"The dearest idol I have known
What e'er that idol be
Help me to tear it from thy throne
And worship only thee

What is it to be a Christian: II Cor. 5:17, Col. 1:27
Introduction- Have no theories- but let God speak
= The Bible teaches that there is a time when a man is not a Ch'n
"Havng no hope and without God in the world."
= Instances- Matthew, Peter, James, John, 3000, Paul, Lydia, Eunuch, Cornelius, Phillipian Jailer &c- 
= The change from one to the other indicated by 
"New Creature". "Old Things"- "New Things" - "Old man" - "New Man"
"Aliens" - "Citizens". "Afar off" - "Nigh" - "death" - "life".
"darkness" - "light" - "Power of Satan" - "unto God" - 
Born again etc
= Radical expressions.
= Requiring an experience.
= The medium by which this experience is brought to pass is X -
Two expressions which show Chist's relation to this change + "If any man be in X &c
"Christ in you the hope of glory"

Being in Christ
Christ abbreviated X
Being in X and having X in us -
1. In X = a new standing before God -
no condemnation John 3:18; 5:24 -
X becomes a refuge - 
Sin is forgiven -
to get with X - we are to "believe on him" - "receive"
"come to Him" -
2. X in us . = to have this spirit - nature - disposition
this means a "new heart" _ carnal mind has no such spirit.
= this is brought about only by Gods spirit
"Born of the Spirit." John 3:5 Born of God John:1:12,13
= Then we begin to act christ like - have His disposition
Much stress is laid upon "following" X _ wh means
Imitate - obey - learn - Ills. Copyist - soldier -disciple
Conclusion - 1. Mistake of those who "try to do the best they can"
"Depart from me &c" - Young man who had kept [? the comds? ]  - Paul - By grace
2.  When may we call ourselves Ch'ns ; When we believe & obey -
are you a Ch'n?  If not, why?

The World the Teacher of the Church
The children of this world are wiser in their generation than the children of light.   Luke 16:8
Introduction
According to all right-thinking the wiser should teach the less wise: but the less wise may be wiser than the more wise in Some Things.
Ills.  The Child often teaches the parent 
Proverb "The fool shall be servant to the wise in heart"
Satan and his devices So "wise as serpents" &c
[crossed out:  Lessons from the lower orders - Robert Bruce and the Spider  Oscillation of the lamp - Galileo]
Another important distinction - One class of beings may be wiser for themselves than another
Ills.  Fox wiser for his interest, than in the Rabit.
Bird instinct compared with the fly, moth, Miller
Some dif. bet. species of fish -  Races of Men

This illustrates the teaching of our Lord   Ills State Parable - Quote text. It then follows that the Church may go to School to the world for its wisdom in some things. This does not imply that the ☉[symbol for world] is better than the Church - or more intelligent. We need not be reminded that the Bible Condemns the ☉ [symbol for world] ; and that it is the duty of the Church to instruct and reprove it. But that the ☉[symbol for world] in its generation (sphere]) is practically wiser than the Church in its Sphere. 
Theme- What the Church can learn of the ☉ [symbol for world]. 
Define Wisdom: Highest-sense. Choices of the best Ends. Honest: Shrewd adaptation of means to an End.

5
Ills. This nation expended 3 Thou Million dollars in 4 yrs to save the Union  - Wise       Would it be wise to expend a like amount to overthrow Satans dominion? But the ☉ [symbol for world] shall not always be our teacher. Signs of better Things. Consecration - Wisdom of Endowing Ed. -[?]. Missions Charities - Less Expensive houses Era of woman in Missions. Business men coming to the front with wise tact. Work of prevention is seen to be more important than that of reformation. Ills the Child Drunkany?

In this the  ☉[symbol for world] is found to be the wiser. Refer to Steward In what respects?  Answer the following: 1. As to uninterrupted devotion to its work the ☉[symbol for world] is the teacher of the Church. This object - Self -  He lives for it. Day, hour moment. Thought + dream. Push. rush of business. He is consecrated. It is his bias and tendency. So it should be with the Ch. Ills  ☉ [symbol for world] is "Free from righteousness" The Ch. Should be "free from sin." 2. As to wise fore-cast. Ills the Unjust Steward But we live as if here was no hereafter - spiritually the ☉ [symbol for world] prepares - Educates - trains - We little. ☉ [symbol for world] seises opportunities - We have blind eyes. Ills How a young man gets a home -  one thing at a time -  Apply to Ch. work.

3. As to zeal. It attends to that first which is of highest importance. We ashamed to be zealous. Ills Did you ever see a merchant ashamed to be? Politicians? Pleasure Seekers? (Headaches) How few can say "The zeal of thine house &c" 
4. As to Enterprise. Adapting means to ends at any cost. Faculty for devising methods.  Maxim - Nec's mother of invention.     Ills  Tunnel under lake & R.R. through mountains. sub-marine telegraph, ships R.Rs &c
In secular affairs means are commensurate with the grandeur of the end sought:  In Ch - Enterprise of small acct.   Ch work should be planned with skill [?one?] ☉ [symbol for world]

What Must I do to be saved.
[?]  Concerns only one class- 
Does not concern the infidel.  
Does not concern the indifferent.  
Does Concern the Serious & reflecting mind -
1.  You must do something for you have sinned at least once.
"Cursed is he that continueth not" &c   
"He that keepeth the whole law &c
Rejected - Angels - Adam - The Law of the land
In doing something you must act for yourself -

Paul & Silas did not say 

"Wait - Wait Gods time."
God's time is now.

2. What you do you must do quickly - 
-Command of and [?] to immediate action
-Difficulty of the work surges forth
-Uncertainty of life surges forth
-Ever increasing hardiness of the [?] heart urges
3. The thing you do must be not what you choose to do but what God authorizes you to do.  Unauthorized effort [?] off
4. You may do many things which the Bible approves and yet not do that specific thing attached to the promise of sal.
5. There is only one thing.
6.That one thing is not to make an atonement - nor to make yourself better.
7.  It is no external act - but an act of the soul-

He that hath the Son hath life and he that hath not the Son of God hath not life. 
John 5:12
I. The Condition expressed.- "hath not life" - Dead

3. Contact with Him necessary to life in us.

Christ must touch dead souls - "To as many as received Him" "Except ye eat no flesh" &c
Spiritual life not something outside - "Know ye not how not Jesus X is in you" "Your bodies are the members of X." "Ye in me & I in you." "I am the vine ye are to branches "I am crucified with X nevertheless" "He not eateth my flesh &c" "
Ills. Vegetable life is not contained in a reservoir in the skies &c" Life is in every plant & tree. 
Ills. Magnetise & demagnetise but not so with life.

Spiritual Biogenesis Devin F Drummond
Verily, verily, I say unto you except a man be born of water & of the Spirit &c John 3:5-8.
Introduction. State the law of continuity-applied to life, death, growth, biogenesis. I What is the natural l am of biogenesis?  Two opposite schools in science = Spontaneous Generation - Life only from life. History of the overthrow of the S.G. theory. Dr. Bastian - (See Nat Law in the S. W. 63) Huxley - acknowledges - Nat (e doc r?) life only from life is victorious along the whole line at the present day". Tyndall is also compelled to say: "I affirm that no shred of trustworthy experimental testimony exists to prove that life in our day has ever appeared independently of antecedent life." Two religious schools almost exactly corresp'g

The difference is radical-
S.G in Rel. means that a "man may become gradually better & better until in the course of the process he reaches that underlined quality end underline in religious nature known as Spir-Life". Nothing Ab? extra
On the other hand Spir.Life is the gift of life. New creation born from above.
II. The law illustrated
The mineral and plant king.s staked off
"Passage from one to the other hermetically sealed on the mineral side". (68
Gulf fixed.
Says Dr Stirling: "we are in the presence of the one incommunicable gulf - the gulf of all gulfs - the mighty gulf between death and life."
Says Huxley - "the present state of knowledge furnishes us with no link bet. e living and e not-living."
Says the Author of the "Unseen Universe" -

"All really scientific experience tells us that life can be produced from a living antecedent only."
Apply to spir-life. Acc'd to the law of continuity. The same is true in the spir-sphere. Gulf fixed. Door shut no man can open it. Text - cannot enter - nothing arbitrary scientific impossibility. "No organic change. No modification of surroundings, no mental energy, no moral effort, no evolution of character, can endow any human soul with the att. of spir-Life."
III. This law applied.
Ills "The plant stretches down to e dead world beneath it." 72
Except a mineral to form from above &c.
So apply - Law of Reg good for both worlds
Beginning of life a miracle

Conclusion
1. The proclamation of life from above a necessity. 76+
The mineral can tell us nothing of plant or animal life.
Scientific statement by Paul - the natural man receiveth not &c
Agnostics position.
2. The natural man is dead
3. Central position of Chty confirmed
4. Importance of the doctrine - Literature of the day - 67
5. The mystery of Regen. 80
no less a mystery than the beginning of life in nature.

Sept 26 1880
Reply to Ingersoll's Lecture on "What Must we do to be saved"
I speak as unto wise men; judge ye what I say  1 Cor. 10:15
Introduction
Three points to be considered - 1. Misrepresentation of the Christian System.  2.  Misstatement of facts    3.  Misinterpretation of Scripture.
I.  Misrepresentation -  He charges it with bondage of thought.  Appeal to the exponents of the Ch'n System
1.  The Bible - This summons to thought    The central figure is Christ - And the Principal question - "What think ye of X?"

Paul to Phil's. Whatsoever things are true - "think on these"
Wise man - "Search the reasons of things" -
Isaiah - "Come now and let us reason together"

   "       "Bring forth your reasons."

Paul ' "Give a reason for the hope"
It calls upon us to "Buy the truth"

"   "       "     "   "   "Come to the knowledge of truth" and the truth shall make you free

It calls upon us to submit to God's law - but he calls it the "law of liberty" - 
All souls constructed upon a model of law and can act freely only as it obeys -
It conducts from"darkness to light" - "He that followeth me" &c
Ignorance & Superstition & fanaticism are all put under ban.  "Too Superstituous:  "Zeal without knowledge".
He puts his condemnation upon  those who do not think  "The nations that forget God"

2.  Second evidence is History -
1.  Exponent -  The men who have been foremost in securing freedom of thought in the world have been believers in, and the best interpreters [crossed out: exponents] of the Bible
Wickliffe, Morning Star of Ref [Reformation]
Huss, Martyr
Luther
Melancthon
Hampden - exponent of liberty
Cromwell         "        "  toleration
Milton               "       "  freedom of Press
Whitfield, Clarkson, Wilberforce, & Howard   
Ref - the benevolent principle - Yet all were believers in the Bible - and were good interpreters of its teachings.  They affirmed that it taught freedom to think for oneself and they acted accordingly.

3.  Third exponent is the History of Civil & Rel. freedom - Testimony of Guirot  -  Civil Liberty - Destruction of Feudal System* and transition from Despotism to Monarchy  ^ *See Hand of God in Hist 66.  
Magna Charta 12.15.  Here fall Cromwell and the Puritans -   See also Hand of God 383
4.  Fourth Exponent of Ch'ty is the School System
Universities of Europe - Oxford & Cambridge
Universities of Paris, Prague, Bologna, on the the Continent.  All grew out of Protestantism & Ch'ty.    In America - Yale, Harvard, Brown, Rochester, Union, Princeton, Madison, Williams, Dartmouth, Amherst.   Common Schools also the outgrowth of a moral purpose - not of a utilitarian -
5.  Fifth Exponent is National LIfe - 
England, Scotland, Wales, Germany, America, Japan - See History Ref by Fisher 510+

5

   Such a survey discovers Mr. Ingersole Want of discrimination

1.  Between moral and intellectual sense  "Can I sin against God by thinking?" No.  Because he has no God -  Hence no responsibility.  No taking into acct fact of Sin - which modifies that - and makes Rev. of God nec'y -
2.  Hence does not discriminate bet. a heathen religion and a Revelation.  All religions the same - The dif. is but "[?...ping?] after god" and Obeying a God revealed.
3.  Between abuses of the true Rel. and the genius of Ch'ty - Catholicism not an Exponent   Spain, Italy, Portugal "worst nations" yet religious     France "most prosperous yet infidel See Hist of Ref by Fisher page 511+  Guisot - 48

II  Misstatement of facts.
Concerning Authenticity.  Who wrote the N.T.?  Ans. Nobody knows.   We have found 52 Mss. containing portions of the N.T.  Not exact.    Reply  2000 Gospels 635 Pauls Letters 300 Acts & Catt Ef 240  [?] 106  Arnolds Lectures   30 of these contain the Entire N.T. with few defects   No original Mss. or autographs
2. Reasons - Persecutions & Wars. and - Decline in learning - Spirit in Word 28-9    No production of Antiquity in Autograph of the Author.  See "Spirit in Word" 29  History of Heroditus - not earlier than 10 Century.
More N.T. Mss than of any other Book  How do we know who wrote them - In same way that we determine who wrote any other Books      Arnolds Lects.

7
Apostolic Fathers - Heretics - Enemies   See Spirit in Word 16+   Hopkins Lects 259+  Norton 89     But "no two agree" - of course.  3 reasons - Transcribing - correction of errors - willful additions  Arnolds Lects      How det what is right - Comparison of Mss - Quotations of Fathers - Early versions  - Syriac - Latin
"They were all written in Gr.  Disciples knew only Heb"  False - Hebraistic Greek   Norton 50 - Hopkins 264
"Nobody ever saw orig Heb Mss"  No - because there were none
All written in "Uncial letters" not true Some the greater no. Cursive as 1-10  See Arnolds Lects

10
"It is further admitted that even those Mss. have not been properly translated".  Nothing against the Authenticity of the Gospels - A new translation needed every 50 yrs.
"Christ never wrote a solitary word of the N.T."  What of it?    He never told anybody to write - how does he know?  Suppose he didn't.  "Why was nothing written?"  Because they believed the end of the [earth symbol] was near".
1.  How does Mr. Ingersoll know that nothing was written?   2.  How does he know, if nothing was written that they believed any such thing?
"This Text was not written for hundreds of years after the Apostles were dust.  These facts lived in

8
"And the N.T. was not divided in Chap's & verses even until the year 1551.  Recollect it!"  How fresh!  Wonderful discovery!
"In the original Mss. the Gospels are signed by nobody".   True.  Just as the greater part of the writings of antiquity.  Yet, how does Mr. Ingersoll know so much when he believes there were no originals.
"The epistles are addressed to nobody and signed by the same person".  False!  All addressed and signed but Heb & Epistles of John.

9
"All the addresses, all the pretended Ear marks showing to whom they were written and by whom they were written are simply interpolations.   No authority of scholars  - friends or foes to this effect.
"And everybody who has ever studied the subject knows it."

11
the [?] of Credulity.  They depended upon the inaccuracy of legend."     Ancient revisions - Apost. Fathers - Heretics - Enemies - all agree that such books were in existence during the lives of the apostles - the construction and completion of the canon is another thing - Hopkins 257
"Finally when reduced to writing the same gentleman would write by the Same pass. his idea of it and the next copyist would put that in as a part of the text. and when the Church got into trouble and wanted a pass.  to help it out one was interpolated  to order."   Much of which is true, but what of it?  The same is true of other Mss. of antiquity which are received as genuine.

Conclusion

   What kind of a man is this then who fills the largest Hall and whom the crowd applauds at every sentence?

He has condemned himself by
1.  Willful misrepresentations
2.  Misstatements of facts
3.  False pretentions to thought and scholarship

It has banished slavery from the world, it has diminished the frequency of wars - has led the way in all essential human progress, has given to the world a higher standard of benevolence and has led men to labor disinterestedly for his fellow. And what it has done it is still doing.The Earth is being filled with the knowledge of the Lord as the waters cover the sea.
2. But X is the light of the world in a more specific sense. There is an important sense in which he makes his way into the darkened hearts of men. "The natural man receiveth

19
not the things of the Spirit of God because they are foolishness unto him, neither can he know them because they are spiritually discerned.' There is nothing more common among men than to think they see when they do not. But Christ tells them plainly not having eyes the [sic] see not. neither do they understand. In this carnal security they sit down unconcerned, until God by his Spirit opens their blind eyes to see themselves lost forever without a hope in him. It is at such a time as this that X makes his way into their hearts and lightens up all their being makes them to see their depravity - rebellion and hatred to God and how they may be forgiven. They see, in his light, that sin is a terrible thing - that God is wholly just in sentencing them to death. They see the wisdom & love of God in giving his only begotten Son to die in their stead.  They see their only hope in believing on him - and casting themselves on his mercy. And when that is

20
done, Oh what a change! Christ has displaced the darkness by his own light. He has become to the soul wisdom righteousness santification and redemption. Then it is that old things have passed away and that all things have become new. He sees in Gods lights he thinks Gods thoughts, He reasons from God's standpoint - he stands on God's promise. He has 'passed from darkness to light'. He is led forth with joy. The trees of the field clap their hands and his soul is in harmony with all Gods creations. Now, as no such result as this can be brought about by the sinners own act. Christ becomes to him the light of the world. Many things may be added to our knowledge as facts. Education may do much for us in directing the use of these facts, but the light of X alone can give us a live conception of their moral bearing upon our ...

"All the stars and the moon with them cannot produce day - this is the sun's prerogative. Nor can nature's highest light, the most refined society and morality, make it day in the soul. This belongs to Christ. 
That spiritual sense which was closed up by sin must be opened by X. Reason may display her logic but it can never reveal the truth as it is in Jesus. Men may think they reason correctly when by argument they do away with the necessity of being born again, when if their eyes were open to discern spiritual things their logic would appear to themselves absurd. To judge of a thing correctly one must have personal knowledge of it. To see one must have eyes. Spiritual knowledge requires spiritual Sight. Christ only can give this. But one sun gives light to the world. So there is but one Sun of Righteousness; one son of God; one Mediator between God and man. There is salvation in none other, for there is none other name under heaven given among men whereby one must be saved. 
But the text has something more for us. It says "He that followeth me shall not walk in darkness

22
Here is a condition and a pledge - Man's pathway to heaven will be light only as he follows X. He will be led into the way only as he follows the light of truth. The inquiring soul after Christ must follow X. The way will be made plain, the evidences of acceptance will be made clear only in the attempt to do the will - the whole will of God. He that doeth his will shall know of the doctrine.' If you cannot comprehend fully the truth of God, follow X. If you are in doubt as to any doctrine follow X - do his will & you shall know whether it be true or false. God's word for it, my friends. This is the remedy for scepticism and doubt. You need not sit there doubting the truth of these things for a moment - Christ offers to throw light upon your difficulties - Follow him. If any man lack wisdom let him ask of God. Solve spiritual problems by

23
spiritual rules. And what is good for the sinners in these respects is good for the Christian. Darkness, desprudency, and cold indifference vanish before the light of X. He shines through the means of grace. The places where he has promised to meet his children are lighted up with his presence. His ordinances constantly quiet the light of the cross. Put your souls in contact with them if you would have your darkness and doubt renewed. In hours of trial, suffering affliction or death nothing can take the place of him in whose presence all tears are wiped away, and who has lighted up the grass? and made it but the shadow of death. x But we must look a moment at an other part of the picture - the result to ourselves if we turn our eyes away from this light. Christ has said that the world lies under condemnation - and this is it - that light

24
is come into the world and men loved darkness rather than light because their deeds were evil. Think of it unconverted friend. You have affected your own condemnation by choosing darkness rather than light of X. You have preferred to live in your own light, but "the light of the wicked is sin" You remember Gods woe upon them that put darkness for light and light for darkness. The world is so much in your eye that you can see nothing else. The apostle says of such cases - "If our Gospel be hid, it is hid to them that are lost, in whom the God of this world hath blinded the minds of them which believe not, lest the light of the glorious gospel of Christ, who is the image of God should shine unto them." If the Gospel is dark to you - it is a token of your lost Conditions - and lost because the God of this world hath blinded your minds. If you expect to have with God forever you must not hate this light. For God is light.

25
eternity is light - heaven is light: there will be no night there. May God shine into your hearts by faith in Jesus X. When Christ left the world he ordained that his people should be lights in his stead. "You are the lights of the world." If Christ be not in a soul that soul is darkness not in darkness but darkness itself. On the contrary Christ in the soul makes that soul light - not brings it into light but it becomes light itself - The divine injunction is - "let your light so shine before men that they may see your good works." Walk as children of light. The might is far spent the day is at hand, let us therefore cast off the works of darkness, and let us put on the armor of light. Let us not sley as do others, but let us watch and be sober. If X is the light of the world what an inducement to carry it to the

  The morning light is breaking
  The darkness disappears

Let us all have a part in ushering in this glorious dawn upon many a heart. and so receive the fulfillment of the promise. "They that are wise shall shine as the brightness of the firmament and they that turn many to righteousness the stars forever and ever." This is the is the best Christmas greeting that can be given to us all -

Being without sin and it did not [unclear] of hypocrisy or false pretention x There was no evidence of pride. for the argument he uses is just the reverse of this. His promises are made with the power to fulfill. His in-

Then follows - "Learn of me - for I am meek and lowly in heart and ye shall find rest.    +  First "Come" and then "learn" - This is gods order. It cannot be reversed.    ¶   But being made in the likeness of men, Christ was also made under the law.  In one sense there could have been no humiliation in this for ^the glory of   Christ is his obedience to the will of the Father - all good beings have ever been and will ever be subject to Gods law.  But his humiliation under the law was, that being made under the law he was made under the Curse.  Not that he was guilty, but that he was the representative of the guilty.  He was treated by the law as though he had been a Sinner.  The law arraigned him before its tribunal and condemned him to bear the punishment which was due to the sinner.

"A more humiliating situation cannot be conceived.  The Son of God is treated as the meanest and vilest of mankind.  The law made no concession to his dignity; it waived none of its rights in crossed out: its ^his favor, and nothing less would satisfy it than his blood."

9.
And this you will remember that this condition of Christ was not supervened upon him by an arbitrary appointment, it was an essential part of a great plan originating in the wisdom and justice of God for the manifestation of his glory in the redemption of the world. The reason is made clear and grand in these words - "Although he was rich yet for our sakes". Yes, see the reason for Gods singular plan. "for our sakes he became poor. that we through hims poverty might become rich."  In Childhood, he was dependent like other children upon others, and subject as are they to inattention, neglect, awkwardness and ignorance. And even when he grew up to be a man. his condition seemed to be in nowise changed from that of others. He was doomed to an occupation. To gather the necessities of life by the work of his family.

10
thus the Lord of all was reduced to a level with the lowest of the human race and litterally underwent that part of the curse which doomed man to Earn his bread by the sweat of his brow. There is one thought of comfort in this however. That while it was humiliating to him - the hand which he put to toil has forever made it honorable - and when we work and sweat and suffer we may remember that our Lord has gone before us in all these things. When his public life rests we unvarying seal "He was a man of sorrows and acquainted with grief. Although it is not said that Jesus was sick, it is said that he was hungry, weary, thirsty, and was subject to excessive cold and heat. to disappointment, sorrow vexation and he pangs of unrequited kindness and violated friendship. To these were added he the hardships of actual poverty. Christ was literally poor. The possessor of heaven

11
and Earth had not where to lay his head The lowliest Cottage in Judea he could not call his own. Women ministered to him, which in those days was no honor - and his daily bread came from the hand of hospitality. He was taxed for temple tribute as was others but had nothing to pay & had to work a miracle to obtain the small sum. In his public ministry he was loved by some and hated by others. Called all manner of names by the unrighteous Pharisee. as a drunkard- glutton- friend of publicans and sinners. His feelings, for he had sensibilities such as we, are expressed in such prophetic words as these- "Reproach hath broken my heart, and I am full of heaviness, I looked for some to take pity but there was none, and for comforters but I found none." 
¶ To the hostility of man was added that of the old Serpent. Who shot arrows at him in the wilderness. Mocked him upon the pinnacle and tore his holy soul in Gethsemane.  Yet he

12
Exclaims "The prince of this world cometh and findeth nothing in me." But this list of sorrow is carried a step beyond this. Divine wrath was the must severe.  "It pleased the Lord to bruise him". To this he was exposed not as the Son of God simply but as the substitute of guilty men who had engaged to bear their griefs and carry their sorrows. It was with our sins that God was displeased. Hence Jesus in the garden being in an agony, bodily and mentally, prayed more Earnestly and his sweat was as it were great drops of blood fallling down to the ground. Ah, nothing but the burden of our guilt could have made him prostrate there.  Nothing but an appalling sense of Almighty vengeance could have extorted from him the thrice repeated prayer. "Father if it be possible let this cup pass from me."  Follow him now through the brief space that brought him

13
to the mighty deed which shook the Earth but brought life and immortality to light. Seized by officers - better named ruffians - he was dragged before the high priest as a felon. Condemned - led to the Roman Cross, was nailed  there, and there died. receiving the ignominy of and contempt of all nations as expressed in that universal proverb. "Cursed is any one that hangeth on a tree."
¶ Gathering up these thoughts which have but briefly scanned the career of Christ we can but be impressed with a sense of the deep humility unto which Christ plunged when he left his throne to enter our world. And when Christ says learn of me - he proposes to teach us from his own experience. Christ gives us little of abstract theory.  He goes before us in experience and then says "follow me: But the road which Jesus trod led him through the valley of humiliation. Shall we tread there we must if we would follow him.

14
II  In the Second place let us look at the principles which Christ taught as illustrating the humility which he requires. 

  Beginning with the Sermon on the Mount. he taught that "Blessed are the meek for they shall inherit the Earth." But do the meek inherit the Earth? Is there any one class of men who hold the exclusive right to the possessorship of this world?   We answer yes. Meekness of spirit is connected with rest of mind- and this makes much out of little. Pride breeds discontent and the proud and restless do no inherit the Earth though it be in their hands. The humble Christian is richer in his humble cottage than the proud man in the possession of the world. And the wise man made no mistake when he said - "a little with the fear of the Lord is better than great treasure with trouble therewith."

15
Our Lord tells us of two men who went up unto the temple to pray - the one a Pharisee and the other a publican.- one a proud zealot - and the other of little account n his own eyes. The one muttered to God such expresses as these.  "I thank thee that I am not as other men are."  While the publicans prayed- "God be merciful to me a sinner" and smote on his breast. "I tell you says X this man went down to his home justified rather than the other and this is the principle illustrated by the parable "for every one that exalteth himself shall be abased and he that humbleth himself shall be exalted."  X Spares neither individuals nor Communities, what is the duty of one is the duty of the other as lo the exercise of that grace. and what is the woe of one is the woe of the other if it is discarded. That was a fearful doom to which he subjected that proud City of Lake Gallilee. "And thou Capernaum which art exalted to heaven shall be brought down to hell.

16
for if the mighty works which have been done in thee had been done in Sodom it would have remained until this day.  Could we have been with Jesus we would have seen at one time Mary sitting at his feet -  at another time. himself taking a little child and setting him in the midst of his disciples, to teach them that no pride is tolerated in the kingdom of heaven and summing up the full significance of the act he gave us this guide to the entrance upon the way of life. "Except ye be converted and become as little children ye shall not enter into the kingdom of heaven. Whosoever shall humble himself as this little child the same is greatest in the Kingdom of heaven. At another time we would have seen him even when his soul was sorrowful at the last supper- take his towel and going from

17
one to another wash the disciples feet and wipe them with the towel whereunto he was girded." and this act also he embodied in a command  "That in love we should serve one another." 
And what Christ taught his immediate disciples we find exemplified in the lives of those who followed. Hear Paul, who was Chief among the Apostles say, I am not meet to be called an Apostle" "Less man be least of all Saints." "Sinners of whom I am Chief." Hear the Commands he gives- "Be not high minded but fear."   "Humble yourselves in the Light of the Lord"  "Humble yourselves under the mighty hand of God."   And the apostle James seems ever prolix in the abundance of the warnings he gives against heart pride - as though it was and would ever be the besetting sin of the Church of Christ. He draws the contrast as follows- "Let the brother of low degree rejoice in that he is exalted

18
but the rich in that he is made low because as the flower of the Grass he shall pass away.  Indeed, a strong expression is used to indicate the utter impossibility of any progress being made toward God while the heart is under the Control of pride - "God resisteth the proud but giveth grace to the humble."
III.  But Christ goes a step farther and gives us an idea of the Character of the humility which he requires us to Exercise.  Learn of me for I am meek and lowly in heart   It is a heart  grace. There is in it no appearance of affectation.  "Ye shall know them by their fruits."   It is difficult to counterfeit it - though so often tried.  Its substitute is easily detected - It is the pure gold of a Christian life - a life hid with Christ in God.  It is as natural to the Christian who walks with God as any natural born trait of Character.

19

Let us first
I    Look  at the innumerable sources - the broad range of circumstances which promote this evil.  Let us start in with that inborn bent of the soul which comes into life with us. Who of us but believes in the well authenticated fact that our bodies inherit a variety of forms and features - the result of prior forces

6
no man comes into this world a perfect ideal. Who is the man that possesses the matchless symmetry of the Apollo Belvidere! Deficiencies mark the fairest features. The chin is too short the forehead is too retreating, the limbs are awkward. The body is too round or too spindling or something else is defective. How this great variety of form and feature is inherited - not perhaps altogether from the immediate parents but from some part of the genealogical line.

 So it is of the Soul. It is a false theory that the soul come into the world - "a round soul - unmarred; a white soul, unstained; that if it could be shielded from the intrusion of false teaching & temptation, and undiverted in its tendencies every one alike might go a while robed angel, up to God unchallenged." Neither the Bible nor science ratifies this view. The theological teaching is "that in Adam all die". Its counterpart

7
is found in our observation confirmed by the researches of science. How many a son has inherited the appetite that responded to the glitter of the wine in the wine cup at the first opportunity and was captured by the moving of the serpent - aright, as it fixed its basilisk eye upon him. A young man who had not seen his father for nineteen years from his infancy away so perfectly reproduced his fathers peculiarities that the relationship could be easily detected by " his way of drawing on his boots". He world is full of confirmatory illustrations.

Take the mental characteristics of men. Brain structure  differs. Begin with genius. This is a born quality. No man acquires it Prof.  Truman Henry Safford formerly of the University of Chicago is a Mathematical genius. He was always above school regulations and restrictions. He had a way of his own. He finished

8
Adam's new Arithmetic in 4 days before he was 6 years old - at 9 he prepared an almanac - at 10 he accomplished the feat of multiplying 18 figures by 18 figures in one minute mentally and giving the correct result. All higher calculations were child play to him. He reached results by intuition. While other men arrive at conclusions by rectangles he goes straight up the hypotenuse. 
¶ But even among the masses of men is formed a great variety of differences. Some are quick and others are slow. Some seem to leap over obstacles others approach them by slow marches. x  In temperament also one is amiable and another is harsh; one is impulsive and another is prudent. Now, while these determinate proclivities do not necessarily fix the destiny of men, they do greatly complicate its solution.  They teach us that we are not so much kings over ourselves as we supposed, and that a stronger hand

9.

than ours is needed for the fashioning of our lives and Character.  But all these complications of hereditary characteristics make up the first growth of our prejudices. We are born prejudiced.
Then what of after life.  Think of the multitude of circumstances which lend their influence to the moulding of our beliefs.  Socrates once said concerning prejudice. that "there is no one who has not grown up under a load of beliefs - beliefs which he owes to the accidents of Country and family, to the books he has read, to the Society he has frequented, & to the Education he has received." and "through these as through a prism he views and judges the objects of knowledge."  The process of education may in fact be like giving the plant light and air, but many times it is more like the process

10
of the Chinese dwarfing the foot or of the Indians flattening the head. Now it is giving a round full Enlargement to the character. Truth to be seen aright must have a perfect character.  Christ as a perfect man saw truth as we never can see it. Hence the pure in heart only can see God. A very little thing may be the starting point of a prejudice. It is wonderful how some casual word manner or circumstance is caught up like driftwood in the current of Character forming a ripple or new Channel in all afterlife. If is said of Dr. Channing the great Unitarian divine that when a little child he went to meeting with his father where the doctrine of endless punishment was very solemnly preached. his father being a believer in that doctrine. After the sermon his father left the meeting house whistling and that whistle was the seed of the boy's subsequent theology. To him it was a mockery of the fearful words he had just heard. He could not.

11
see how a man could whistle so carelessly after expressing the thought that his fellow men were writhing in Everlasting torment.  It was but a trifle,  but it sent him to the other pole of theological belief. 
But prejudice frequently takes the form of tradition or custom.  "As did their fathers, so do they unto this day," was said of a nation who feared the Lord and served their graven images." Our Lord met with this form as an Element of hostility to his work and was the Chief inspiration which led to his Crucifixion.  We attach great reverence and authority to the sayings and doings of our fathers not thinking perhaps that their views and beliefs were received in modified forms from their ancestors and that we are swallowing without stoping to taste a mixed cup of human prejudices colored perhaps by a few grains of truth.  Ch. membership

Then what is public opinion, which rules almost as sole monarch of the day. but the mere adoption by the masses, without thought or investigation, of opinions advanced by certain leaders be they politicians - reformers or theologians. Really, ignorance is at the root of prejudice. A man of strong prejudices is generally a man of fearful ignorance in some things at least. A man by shutting himself up at home, depriving himself of all society superior to those around him may come at last to think himself a king of [sic: or] pope but let him break through his seclusion and he will be surprised to find that he has thought "himself to be something when he was nothing."Sometimes we get strange notions into our heads respecting our particular denominations or church. Confined almost wholly within the circle of home - we talk of our church as the biggest - our Sunday School as the best our denomination as the most prosperous

13.
and only see what great things we are doing. The world will soon come over to us. All Christians will in time be Congregationalist or Methodists or Disciples or whatever the case may be. But let us get out of our tracks a little and we will see that other denominations are thriving just as well and perhaps a little better than our own.
As a matter of fact then when we conclude that we are dispassionate- unprejudiced, unbiased in our investigations of truth we may labor under a fearful hallucination. It is not so we are all more or less prejudiced.
II  But the ground we have thus traversed has only shown us some of the multiplied sources of prejudice, without giving us a practical idea of the greatness of the evil.

Others of the Jews said "We know this man whence he is"  and therefore rejected him because he was the Carpenters son - At another time they said "We know that God spoke unto Moses; but as for this fellow, we know not from whence he is." and they rejected him on this ground. so that in either case prejudice ?nited?  ?utt unbelief - and Christ became the "despised and rejected of men." And so I suppose it is today - Men allow their prejudices to keep them out of the kingdom of X. At one time their prejudices tell them that they know all about this matter

Dr Taylor of Norwich, once said to John Newton, "Sir, I have collated every word in the Hebrew scriptures 17 times, and it is very strange that the doctrine of Atonement which you hold has not been found by me." To this Newton replied "I am not at all surprised at this, I once went to light my candle with the extinguisher on it." Now, prejudice from education learning - habit &c often proves an extinguisher. It is not enough that you bring the candle _ to the study of Gods word, you must remove the extinguisher. Ills.  The distinguishing doctrines of the Bible

16
which are so unpalatable to men - but so essential to their eternal life are rejected not because men cannot understand them and see a reason for them - but because prejudice has turned their hearts away from their contemplation. (Ills "Except ye becomerled? " &c)   And what means this endless variety of sects in Christendom? Why so many churches of different orders all crowding into one small community? What of all these strifes, and bickerings and bitterness even among the followers of X? Answer. Largely Prejudice. Of some men you can say he was born a Baptist - or he was born a Methodist. These characteristics have been so well defined that you can predict with a good degree of accuracy where a man will join before he is converted - just from his temperament and make up of his mind. But if these traits are not born in him he is educated

17

This prejudice  often carries men bodily as it were over to hatred of all others who disagree with them. Not that there is any assignable tresspass in the Case - but because they are on the opposite side and must be wrong of course, and must be stupidly wrong. For instance if you are asked why you dislike that man over there, why you wont associate with him, why you all the while insinuate that he is a bad man - you would be ashamed to say it is because he is a Democrat and I am a Republican or it is because he is a Baptist and I am a Methodist, yet in many cases those would be correct answers. Two Christian neighbors live side by side for years when it is observed they have no dealing with one another.

their Children have no interplay.  In church they have their pews separated from each other as far as possible.  In all Church differences they take opposite sides. It was a little splinter in the flesh at first - but festered and made a fearful sore.
The preaching of the gospel becomes vain when poured into [crossed out: under the influence of} prejudiced ears.  The style of the preacher - his habits of thought - his manner of dress - all these may be peculiar to himself and so make him different from all other men - and being different he runs [att?art?] the peculiar Education of his hearers under other men.  an old man was once seen

"Do you think I would hear that billy-goat preach?" said the indignant old man who was very sure that no orthodox gospel could come from between heterodox whiskers. Trifles as light as this are magnified by prejudice from mole hills into mountains. It sometimes takes sides with passion, self will and self interest in depreciating, vexing and overthrowing the influence of some noble and faithful but sensitive Christian worker.  X was killed by passion & prejudice joined hand to hand. The disciple must not be above his Lord. And many a disciple has met the same fate. To carry the illustration a slip further. I believe that more homes are blighted, more characters are ruined by sly innuendoes aimed by prejudice than

20
by all actual transgressions in such cases put together. it is known that the cannon ball kills by concussion as well as by direct shot. See how it goes - Some busy body  surmises that a certain person may not be all right. In a conversation with a neighbor he is cautioned against that man - Well but what is the matter? O I don't know, I would not say anything to injure him of course - but, you had better look out for him. That is enough to give prejudice a foot hold in the whole neighborhood. Many a man and woman as pure as the snow has been sent down to infamy by just such mention and devilish insinuations. O what a load of just such sins have the people of this day to account for in the day of judgment!

Every many original sin will be added to the list of his actual transgressions in the day of judgment unless they are atoned for and overcome by the blood of X. And he is to meet and overcome prejudice as a trait of character? just in the same way as he would meet and overcome any other bias of his mind, and if he does not he must suffer the consequences. But suppose he can't overcome - It is not a supposable case - He can over come

 God meets us at points where we do not expect him. The Bible came from the hands of men which we would not have appointed. But it comes with? O Lord revive thy work in the midst of the years, in the midst of the years make known; in wrath remember mercy.
Hab- 3:2 This phrase is underlined twice
It is supposed that this prayer of the prophet Habakuk was offered in anticipation of the Babylonian Captivity of the Jews.  The judgments of God were hard underlined upon them.  The prophet prays, "O Lord revive thy work" & 'In the midst of these years of awful judgments and gloom, let thine own work be preserved, and cause that these Calamities which have overtaken they people on account of their sins may be made the means of blessing to Him."  people crossed through twice.  The ground of necessity for this prayer was in the declension of the people from obedience to God.  Religion is a matter of obedience.  Disobedience brought death.  Obedience is the condition to which we are restored by Christ.

The power that restores  us is constantly needed to keep us - Without the spirit of God to move men they never would obey the Commands of God.  Man has no Characteristic
more marked than his reluctance to do the will of God. If his inclination was to obey, there would be no occasion for this prayer - "O Lord reveal thy work."  Man is so sluggish in his spiritual nature, and so susceptible to influences and excitements that tend to drum him away from duty, that God has found it necessary to awaken him and check his rebellious career by counter excitement even greater in power than those operating against him without these movements of God - these interpositions - even his own people would not obey  And this must ever hold true so long as the Church is governed by so little principle and is so poorly instructed as to what constitutes the Christian life. Tides of worldliness must be met by tides of religious power until the Church is sufficiently well educated in principle to hold steadily on its course. This is true philosophy and is consistent with the facts of history  Ills.

3
The terms revival, awakening, and reformation have come to mean the same thing. An unusual measure of the Holy Spirit among the people, beginning at the "house of God."
X The lamented Finney says in his "Revival lectures" that a "Revival of religion" presupposes a declension." This is the true and original meaning. It refers to Gods people. A true revival of religion can only take place in hearts where religion exists. That which has no existence cannot be revived. The broader meaning of the term which includes conversion came very naturally into use. Whenever Gods people are revived - that is, get near to God - get their hearts cleansed - made tender - made to see & feel the worth of perishing souls, then conversions inevitably follow. The Church is in its normal state only when its relation to God is such as to produce conversions -    In speaking of a revival there we have

4
two things in view - the quickening of Saints and the Consequent Conversion of Sinners. We cannot reasonably expect this order will be changed x If God condescends sometimes to save souls over the slumbering bodies of his people, it is not for us to think that he will always do so. Judgment must first begin at the house of God. If many souls are to be saved - many Christians must be waked up. Ordinarily, God works on the principle of Contact. He saves one soul, and through him he works to save others. He puts one praying heart into a family and makes the Salvation of all the rest dependent upon the faith of that one - Parable of the leaven?  In this way Conversions are multiplied - and the revival becomes general. Mr. Barnes says take the case of a single true conversion to God & extend it to a Community - to many individuals passing through that change and you have all the theory of a revival

5
of religion. It is bringing together many Conversions, arresting simultaneously many minds; perhaps condensing into a single place and into a few weeks the ordinary work of many places and many years." A genuine revival of religion is simply this, and nothing more x All that which is objectionable is not inherent in the idea of revival x "Means" and "Measures" may be wrong; but the quickening of Gods people and the conversion of sinners cannot be wrong, but must ever be right.  The Bible recognizes just such phenomenon.  God has promised to answer prayer by "terrible things in righteousness"x  He describes the decent of the Holy Spirit upon a Community, as a "rushing mighty wind." - like "floods upon dry ground" and like rain upon mown grass - The effect of His Coming is to "make His people willing in the day of His power." The prophet

6
catching a glimpse of the days when the spirit should be "poured out" upon all flesh cried, "Lift up thine eyes and see; all they gather themselves together, they come to thee, the abundance of the sea shall be converted unto thee, and the forces of the Gentiles shall come unto thee."  "Who are these that fly as a cloud and as the doves to their windows"?  When the fullness of time came the "Kingdom of heaven was taken by force"  Indeed a time as mentioned in prophesy when a nation should be "born at once."  These phenomena of great spiritual excitements are formed throughout the entire history of the Church.  "Look back at the history of the Jews, and you will see that God used to maintain religion among them by special occasions, when there would be a great excitement, and people would turn to the Lord. And after they had been thus received, it would be but a short time before there would be

7
so many contradictory influences brought to bear upon them, that religion would decline and keep on declining, till God could have time - so to speak- to shape the course of events so as to produce anther excitement and then pour out his spirit again to convert sinners. When Habakkuk prayed "O Lord revive they work in the midst of the years, in the midst of the years make known, in wrath remember mercy" he prayed for a revival. But long before this in the days of Samuel when the people had strayed from the Lord serving Baalim, it is said "Israel lamented after the Lord" and Samuel said - "If ye do return unto the Lord with all your hearts, and serve him only, he will deliver you." That deliverance came. When they went

into battle with the Philistines "the Lord thundered with a great thunder upon them and discomfited them, and they were smitten before Israel."
Then, it is said, they came to ...

gether and "drew water and poured it out before the Lord" - an emblem it is thought of the fullness of their sorrow for their sins and of their sense of the Lords blessing. That was a revival with great power & result. This was but one refreshing of the ancient days. The Spiritual life lf the O.T. Church ebbed and flowed - through all its history. At times "hope almost expired;" but a remnant was always left of those that feared the Lord". In the reigns of David, Solomon, Asa, Hezekiah and Josiah seasons of recovery and refreshing were often enjoyed - David prays for a revival after the Jews had come back from Babylon. The people gathered themselves together at Jerusalem and commanded Ezra to bring out the book of the land of Moses. And he read it to them "from morning till midday." They could not seemingly get enough of the word of God. And when he blessed the Lord - All the people answered Amen, amen lifting up their hands and worshiping the Lord with their faces on the ground. That was a revival. They had dishonored the Lord - had despised his worship and his word - But now they made haste to do works meet? for repentance - They restored the true worship - they broke up heathen alliances, or in other words, as we would say - separated themselves from the world, and began to contribute again to the support of the temple services.

People of today would have said that that was nothing but excitement.  But not many years after this another excitement followed, Jesus had ascended to the right had of God - to the place of power - Then the prophecies of old and the fresh promise of X was fulfilled The spirit was poured out. It came too in answer to prayer -  A little obscure

band had been praying in an upper room. Answers of peace came after they had waited 10 days. It came like a baptism. It filled the place. It was by the proper influence of truth that the multitudes were alarmed and

11
awakened, and why should not the same truth produce the same effect now: It was indeed by the power of God. But that same power is expected in the conversion of every sinner now.  But there is something significant in the fact that God has provided certain means and agencies which if faithfully used will always result in

12

Rev. A. B. Earle the distinguished Evangelist says of these - "God who cannot make a mistake, and who knows all about the difficulties to be overcome - in a dark, cold time, bids us to & preach, pray, exhort and sing in simple faith and he will bless, I have come to believe that God means just what He says in his word. Just so when Jesus says to preach my word, and, lo, I am

13

He will be a saver of life unto life or death unto death.   Again, we must remember that this is in exact accordance with Gods willingness and desire to save men. His heart and his hand are both engaged to bring salvation And is it anything to be wondered at that after he has given his only son a sacrifice - and has revealed his will concerning us and has made the way so plain - if scores & hundreds & thousands, even, should simultaneously desert the city of destruction and turn into the way of life - Is it not rather

14
the strangest of all strange things that all do not at once fly to the arms of mercy?

Besides, see how God is honored by the seasons of salvation. If a soul is saved it must be according to the plan of God - Every part of that plan is honored. It honors the sovereignty of God. It is by sovereign grace that we are all saved, not by works lest any man should boast. Jesus is honored, for he sees of the travele of his soul and is satisfied. He reaps the fruit of his love and death. The Holy spirit is honored - for no man can come to Christ except the Fall? draws him by his spirit. He must be convinced by the spirit of his sins. He must be born of the spirit x  The word of God is honored - for "it is the power of God unto Salvation unto every one that believeth." The Church is honored

Is there not some ground here for us to base our faith upon in praying for a revival?  Then look out upon the history of revivals  it has been said by one that the history of revivals is the history of religion. When Rome overshadowed the world as a fall of night - Gods word, first in the mouth of John Wyckliffe as the morning star of the reformation, broke the spell. Luther followed as the son of thunder. But he did nothing but to brave the bulls of the pope and preach in the face of death the simple and yet mighty truth that the just shall live by faith. Who shall say that the result which followed was not a revival. And who shall

16
[in]timate its blessings upon the world? Have we not a right to go into this work with all confidence that if we are ourselves first revived we shall see the mighty salvation of God x  The history of revivals proves conclusively that while certain seasons have been marked as revival seasons yet that God is not himself dependent upon times & seasons in saving men. Nothing stands out with greater promise

in all this history than that when ever Gods own people were awake to a full sense of their duty to the world around them -  Sinners were heard crying for mercy

But let us turn our thoughts for a moment to consider what are

  Our obligations to such a Work

Primarily of course our obligation gives? out of what X has done for us. He died for us and we are his - under everlasting obligation to him - to serve him to love him and honor him.

19
Our indebtedness to him is to be discharged in proportion as we succeed in perfecting ourselves and in saving others - O what heavy debts we are carrying, saved ourselves, but we have saved nobody else!   Our obligation to revival efforts will appear in answering two questions:  What have revivals done for the world; and what have they done for us personally? No one sermon is sufficient to adequately reply to either if these inquiries.  We must be content with the merest outline   Take the first question   Think of it first in its most general aspect - What society is not made the better for a work of this kind. Conversions may be but few in comparison with the multitude of unsaved but the very springs of society feel the uplifting power of Grace. "Exalted to be the sons of God, and thrilled with new impulses, men burst asunder the chains of superstition, tyranny and vice and come into a higher and broader

20
development. The fountains of life are purified, and a social and civil reformation is the result."  Dr. Fish of Newark, N.J. in his recently published Hand book of Revival makes the following interesting statement: We boast of the progress of this age; and nothing is more astonishing than the recent advancement in science, philosophy, invention, learning, philanthropy, and civil jurisprudence. But this is attributable in great part to the religious awakenings of the last 300 years. An aroused intellect has been back of all this. Revivals of religion are favorable to intellectual action, not only as they bring the mind at the time into vigorous exercise and into contact with the mighty truth of Gods word but as they originate in the subjects of their moral feelings and habits which are peculiarly favorable to the acquisition

21 
of useful knowledge. Pure minds are the best thinkers. The man who thinks most in accordance with Gods thoughts is the most profound. This is just the mission of the Gospel.  Let us verify it in a single instance. John Wyckliffe dared to unseal the Bible in the face of Rome. What followed is known by the "revival of letters." Twenty four universities arose in less than a hundred years. See the men which that revival produced. The names of Luther, Zuinglius, Cranmer, Melancthon, Knox, and Calvin - constitute but one constellation of northris? - Soon followed another - Owen, Bunyan, Baxter Milton, Leighton and Flavel with their works. If you have ever taken delight in Paradise Lost by Milton, Pilgrims Progress & "Grace abounding to Chief of Sinners" by Bunyan - or the Fountain of Life & Method of Grace by Flavel you may thank God for the revival of the 16th & 17th Centuries. The Pilgrims & the Puritans

22.
of the American Colonies were also the direct
product- of the revivals in the old world.
America was cast in the mould of
a revival Spirit. Otherwise it could never have been said. 
When driven by oppressions rod 
Our fathers fled beyond the sea
Their care was first- to honor God
and next to leave their children free.
Above the forests' gloomy shade
The altar and the school appeared
On that the gifts of faith were laid
On this their precious hopes were reared. 

 But-not-to prolong these remarks 

let it be said that all missionary movements had their origin directly in the revival of the 17th century.  All the
great benevolent enterprises which are the glory of this age - date back to that wonderful revival. The first concert of prayer for For. Missions of which we

23
we have every record since the dark ages originated in a Baptist Association in Nottingham Eng - where it was determined that one hour in the first Monday evening of every month should be devoted to special intercession for the Redeemers kingdom throughout the earth." Shortly after, William Carey preached the first Missionary sermon - from the text "Enlarge the place of thy tent" - urging that we were to "Expect great things from God and attempt great things for God"  And is it not a wonderful thing that all the first For-Missionaries, such as Hall, Newell, Mills, Judson, Nott, Rice, and others were converted in revivals - and then received their missionary impulses!  It has also been ascertained that at least nine tenths of all the ministry of all ages were brought into the kingdom and into the pulpit through the agency of revivals. Institutions of learning have a similar origin - Princeton and Dart-

24
[Dart]mouth sprang out of one revival. Yale began without such influences but from the testimony of Dr Dwight its first president we learn that its life was feeble and sickly until a revival in 1802 shook the whole College and it seemed for the time that the whole mass of the students would press into the Kingdom. and nearly all the converts entered the Ministry. Brown University, Amherst College, Middlebury College & others which might be mentioned have passed through a similar history. Positive testimony from all these institutions is to the effect that their past usefulness and present prosperity have been largely due to the influence of revivals.

 Then for a moment we must look out upon a still broader field. Where have our Churches come from? How have our strong churches been built up?

25
Let the following figures tell in part the story.

 During the awakening between 1730-1745 50,000 were converted. 40,000 more annually from 1790-1840 and 400,000 more in the year 1857-8.  Does not this tell us where our Churches come from? Make it still more a personal matter. Where did you find peace? In a revival or not? If not in a revival did you not first get your eyes open to see your need of a savior there: If the truth could be known I believe the very large majority of believers would date their Conversion back to some awakening. x  Are we then under any obligation to revivals? Let me put it in still another light - Those who have been saved in revivals of course feel under obligations to advocate them - but is there not another class who ought to be thankful for them and welcome them - and do all in their power to promote them:  Who lives in

26
in the light of this age and in the enjoyment of its principles - who boasts of its enlightenment, civilization, morals and its freedom, who is not a debtor for all these things, to a very large extent, to the revivals which have passed into history? It belongs as much to the citizen of today to open wide doors to these agencies as to the mere Christian. There is no denying these facts - Men may cavil and call these awakenings what they please - they may stigmatize those who engage in them as fanatics - yet they are but the parents of their own good. 

 But there is yet another question which I must press upon every person here. If you have passed through such scenes as those I have described - and are not yet saved, let me ask why not! And of every Child of God let me ask, are you revived? If not, why not?
